Issues.Title: fix(language-service): do not return external template that does not exist
Issues.Body:
There is a bug in tsserver that causes it to crash when it tries to create
script info for an external template that does not exist.

I've submitted an upstream PR
https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/pull/41737 to fix this, but before
the commit lands in the stable release, we'll have to workaround the issue
in language service.

Close https://github.com/angular/vscode-ng-language-service/issues/1001

Issues.Title: Load Function for IMG Element Does Not Work As Expected
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Is this a regression? This is the first version of Angular I'm using. But a question on stackoverflow shows this issue was not present before(4 years ago on Angular 2) [Here's the link](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39257687/detect-when-image-has-loaded-in-img-tag) ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... I have an array of objects that contain URL's for several images and I want to show these images on my page. But here's the catch; some images are taller than others or some are wider than others in another statement. So for each picture, to either set their object-fit to scale-down or to cover, I need to know whether the image is wide or tall. I'm trying to get the image's naturalWidth and naturalHight values through the (load) function that Angular provides but the function is repeatedly called for the first element of the array. By repeatedly, I mean for real. The function is getting called for that one element in the array non-stop. the way I'm using it from IMG element ` ` And my function on the background is ``` loadImage(evt){ if (evt && evt.target) { const x = (evt.srcElement as HTMLImageElement).naturalWidth; console.log('x:' + x); if ((x === 0 ) && (y === 0)) { const width = evt.srcElement.width; const height = evt.srcElement.height; let portrait = height > width ? true : false; console.log('Loaded: ', width, height, 'portrait: ', portrait); } } ``` the console output of this function is: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24587852/100654736-52da2280-335b-11eb-9d0f-3b57890111d4.png) (don't mind the socket error) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/... ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 



Angular version: 9.0.1
**Anything else relevant?** I'm using Chrome.

Issues.Title: Better error message when Typescript version isn't correct
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [ ] new
- [X] build
- [X] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] extract-i18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
If the current Typescript version that is installed meets the required version but uses the caret and there is a version that exists that is beyond the required version you get an error:

The Angular Compiler requires TypeScript >=4.0.0 and <4.1.0 but 4.1.2 was found instead.

The current version that was installed is 4.0.5, but in package.json it is ^4.0.5 and 4.1.2 is available. Switching the package.json to ~4.0.5 fixes the issue. 

### Describe the solution you'd like
Add a more descriptive error. In this situation it would be nice if the message was more clear on what needs to change. Something like:

The Angular Compiler requires TypeScript >=4.0.0 and <4.1.0 but the current version in package.json doesn't does not apply this restriction. 

If the actual version does not meet the required version, then the current message is correct. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Fixing the version works, but the message is misleading.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Better error message when Typescript version isn't correct" (#39894)

Issues.Title: Provide an ability to use wildcard (`*`) in ContentChild(ren) queries
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package [ContentChildren](https://angular.io/api/core/ContentChildren) ### Description ContentChildren is the correct (only) tool to access elements within ng-content, correct? We use it to access a QueryList of the elements, very similar to [querySelectorAll](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/querySelectorAll). However, accessing the elements of ng-content **which we do not know ahead of time is not possible.** ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Here is a [stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-focus-cycle-directive?file=src%2Fapp%2Ffocus-cycle.directive.ts) of a directive attempting to access the children of ANY element it is used on with `ContentChildren`. Unless the content contains a template variable, or the selector is known ahead of time, this setup does not work as you'd expect. (A equivalent to querySelectorAll does not exist within Angular?) ## üî• Exception or Error Some template ```
``` Within AnyDirective `@ContentChildren("*") elms!: QueryList; // undefined children` **Angular Version:** 11.0.2
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Provide an ability to use wildcard (`*`) in ContentChild(ren) queries" (#39875)

Issues.Title: [Proposal] Allow referencing the whole TemplateRef context object from the template
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Packages

This feature request is for `@angular/core` and `@angular/compiler`.

### Description

The object used as context for `TemplateRef` is not accessible from the template; only the values of its keys are. Therefore, it's not possible to

1. easily reference keys of a large object, or
2. pass the whole context to another template reference.

For example, consider the following context.

```ts
const context = { foo: 1, bar: 2, baz: 3, qux: 4 }
```

In order to just print all of these values, it's necessary to write the following template.

```html
                   <!-------------- verbose & error-prone --------------->
<ng-template #tpl1 let-foo="foo" let-bar="bar" let-baz="baz" let-qux="qux">
  {{ foo }}, {{ bar }}, {{ baz }}, {{ qux }}
</ng-template>
```

The list of `let-xxx="xxx"` will just keep increasing with the same mundane boilerplate code as the object grows. 

Furthermore, two such templates won't be easily composable, even though they accept the same kind of context.

```html
                   <!-------------- verbose & error-prone --------------->
<ng-template #tpl2 let-foo="foo" let-bar="bar" let-baz="baz" let-qux="qux">
  Elements: 
  <ng-template
    [ngTemplateOutlet]="tpl1"
    [ngTemplateOutletContext]="{ foo: foo, bar: bar, baz: baz, qux: qux }" 
  >
                               <!-------- verbose & error-prone -------->
</ng-template>
```

Apart from `{ foo: foo, bar: bar, baz: baz, qux: qux }` being equally verbose and error-prone as `let-foo="foo" let-bar="bar" let-baz="baz" let-qux="qux"` (especially since there's almost no type checking for these cases), this will create a new object for every CD cycle (more on that below).

### Describe the solution you'd like

A way to get a hold of the context object itself. Templates in the examples above could be rewritten as follows.

```html
                   <!-- <3 -->
<ng-template #tpl1 let-ctx="*">
  {{ ctx.foo }}, {{ ctx.bar }}, {{ ctx.baz }}, {{ ctx.qux }}
</ng-template>
```

```html
                   <!-- <3 -->
<ng-template #tpl2 let-ctx="*">
  Elements:
  <ng-template
    [ngTemplateOutlet]="tpl1"
    [ngTemplateOutletContext]="ctx"
  >
                            <!--<3-->
</ng-template>
```

The precise syntax doesn't have to be like this, but the `*` symbol should ring a bell from the namespaced import syntax `import * as context from 'context'`. I don't think there's issues about confusion with the microsyntax prefix (`*ngFor`, `*ngIf`) since the asterisk in case of `let-ctx="*"` doesn't come as a prefix, and it's placed in the spot where a variable name can otherwise come in.

An alternative syntax that comes to mind would be using `...` which rings the bell of the spread/rest operator, which is similar in nature to what this proposal tries to achieve.

```html
                   <!--  <3  -->
<ng-template #tpl1 let-ctx="...">
  {{ ctx.foo }}, {{ ctx.bar }}, {{ ctx.baz }}, {{ ctx.qux }}
</ng-template>
```

```html
                   <!--  <3  -->
<ng-template #tpl2 let-ctx="...">
  Elements:
  <ng-template
    [ngTemplateOutlet]="tpl1"
    [ngTemplateOutletContext]="ctx"
  >
</ng-template>
```

Ultimately, the syntax isn't the main point of this proposal and these are just examples. I'd love to see others' take on what looks easiest to write and read, and how to make the intent more intuitive based on existing ES and/or Angular constructs.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Obviously, `$implicit` is the alternative. This _seems_ like a good solution:

```ts
const context = { $implicit: { foo: 1, bar: 2, baz: 3, qux: 4 } } // meh
```

```html
<ng-template #tpl1 let-ctx>
  {{ ctx.foo }}, {{ ctx.bar }}, {{ ctx.baz }}, {{ ctx.qux }}
</ng-template>

<ng-template
  [ngTemplateOutlet]="tpl1"
  [ngTemplateOutletContext]="context"
></ng-template>
```

The problem that arises now is that we've changed our model. If we have an array of `User` objects, now we need an array of `{ $implicit: User }` objects. Wrapping objects to an `$implicit` property is something that we'd have to do only because the view requires so. Changing our model to match the view is not how the whole separation of concerns and the model-view architecture is supposed to work (or at least we try to minimize that). The view should be able to adapt to the model, not the other way around.

Now, one way for the view to adopt to the model is, of course, the following.

```ts
const context = { foo: 1, bar: 2, baz: 3, qux: 4 } // good
```

```html
<ng-template #tpl1 let-ctx>
  {{ ctx.foo }}, {{ ctx.bar }}, {{ ctx.baz }}, {{ ctx.qux }}
</ng-template>

<ng-template
  [ngTemplateOutlet]="tpl1"
  [ngTemplateOutletContext]="{ $implicit: context }"
></ng-template>
                             <!-- mixed feelings -->
```

The issue is that this creates a new object `{ $implicit: context }` in every CD cycle. 

Note that [`NgTemplateOutlet` of `@angular/common` itself was changed to check for equality-by-shape instead of equality-by-reference](https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/685cc26ab2dc7f8d836ec932a43d45edfa0f8e97) because it was such a common use-case to create the object inline in the template. That idea introduces more runtime checks in order to allow this common style.

While the solution works, I'm not sure it was a step in the right direction (I'd like to hear what the author of the commit, @pkozlowski-opensource thinks about it). Apart from introducing the runtime check, I feel like it attempts to patch the problem instead of addressing the root cause: the actual _need_ to create objects inline in the template as opposed to just using them from the code -- which is what this proposal is about. Either way, this proposal is not in conflict with the established runtime check-by-shape, so it's not a breaking change; users who worry about performance can create their own variant `NgTemplateOutlet` which only does a simple check by reference.

----

This mostly seems like job for the compiler, as I don't think it introduces any special changes to the core -- that object is already passed around unchanged, and this proposal ‚Äúonly‚Äù allows grabbing the object itself instead of just its keys via `let-localName`.

As usual, ‚Äúonly‚Äù is possibly a rabbit hole of issues. I haven't tried to implement this yet, but I will post here if I manage to get a prototype working for the `let-ctx="*"` syntax (it _looks_ as if it's just a matter of treating `*` as a special case and then passing in `context` instead of `context['*']` for it).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Proposal] Allow referencing the whole TemplateRef context object from the template" (#39884)

Issues.Title: fix(core): better handling of invalid values in `[class]` arrays
Issues.Body:
Currently when a set of classes is represented by an array (e.g. `<div [class]="['a', 'b']">`), there is no
validation for empty and non-string values and as a result, the framework crashes without meaningful errors.

This commit updates the logic to:

- throw more meaningful errors to indicate what is wrong with the input
- handle a case when a value contains leading/trailing whitespaces (e.g. `<div [class]="[' a ']">`) and trims these
whitespaces before further processing (otherwise such values can not be handled by DOM's ClassList correctly).


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(core): better handling of invalid values in `[class]` arrays" (#39883)

Issues.Title: fix(core): remove application from the testability registry when the root view is removed
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->

Issue Number: #22106


## What is the new behavior?

In the new behavior Angular removes applications from the testability registry when the root view gets destroyed. This eliminates a memory leak, because before that the `TestabilityRegistry` holds references to HTML elements, thus they cannot be GCed.


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

Issues.Title: Slots broken in Angular Elements
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report
### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
No. First place would be to look at @angular/elements

### Is this a regression? <!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
Did not test in previous versions.


### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem...
A slot is not effective.
When I run the example application I am expecting the slot to be overridden by the content being passed.
The end result is that it is not being overridden and the default value of the slot is always shown.
Can be seen using simple ng build and opening the index.html in the dist folder in any browser.
To simplify the repository below includes the dist folder as well.

Interesting thing is that if I put a lot of characters in the override slot in the index.html and refresh the browser multiple times, i can see the the slot is being overridden and then the default value is drawn back.
You can see the video of it in the dropbox location.
https://www.dropbox.com/s/olw2xof7y76441e/Angular%20Elements%20Slot.mp4?dl=0
You can see this multiple times in the video like between 3.09 and 3.10 (seconds)

https://github.com/nvsravank/angular-elements

No Exceptions occur

Issues.Title: build: flakes in e2e test in `test_aio(_local(_viewengine))` CI jobs
Issues.Body:
Since recently-ish, the e2e tests in the `test_aio(_local(_viewengine))` CI jobs started flaking. It is not always the same tests that fail and the erros usually get away after a rerun.

Example failuring jobs:
- [862070]
- [862794]
- [862824]
- [862836]
- [862946]

...and more recently:
- [866585]
- [866885]
- [866888]
- [866906]

This might be related to the recent update to CLI v11 and Protractor v7 (with Selenium Promise Manager turned off): #39600

Interestingly, this flakiness doesn't seem to affect docs examples (which have also been updated to CLI v11 and Protractor v7 with disabled Selenium Promise Manager in #39818). But that could be because the `test_docs_examples(_viewengine)` CI jobs [use a `xlarge` executor][1].

Issues.Title: IVY dev server issues that vanish after restart
Issues.Body:
### Description I have the following issue since using Ivy (i personally can confirm the issue exists on Angular 10 and 11). There is some erratic behavior with Angular Ivy - sadly it's completely inconsistent (and i didn't find a way to reproduce it reliably), but it does happen quite often. I am running the dev-server with _ng serve_ and every once in a while (usually after adding some HTML code) the compiler would puke out like 20 messages that make no sense - stuff like "Can't bind to 'ngIf' since it isn't a known property of 'div'". If I revert the most recent change, or comment out the last part of the HTML it works fine, but if i un-comment it the error comes back - reliably, at least in that matter - even if i repeat this 10 times. When i restart ng serve **without changing any code** the errors disappear though. For me the issue happens on different PCs and different projects and with both Angular 10 and 11. I talked to some colleagues and also asked arround on on reddit in this [post](https://www.reddit.com/r/Angular2/comments/k1x0s6/angular_ivy_issues_errors_that_disappear_after/) and got responses that re-assure me that i am not the only one with that issue. Actually I am surprised that no issue exists for this, hopefully I didn't overlook it? Unfortunately due to the "disappearing after restart" - nature of this bug it seems pointless to write a reproducer. I tried to forcible reproduce this error, but simply had no success - funny, since it haunts me to a point were i lost all trust into the compiler and just restart _ng serve_ even before checking my code twice ## üî• Exception or Error 

Error: src/app/administration/administration.module.ts:30:292 - error NG6001: The class 'SerienTerminComponent' is listed in the declarations of the NgModule 'AdministrationModule', but is not a directive, a component, or a pipe. Either remove it from the NgModule's declarations, or add an appropriate Angular decorator.

....

src/app/administration/termin/serien-termin/serien-termin.component.html:1:7 - error NG8002: Can't bind to 'formGroup' since it isn't a known property of 'form'

... (like 20 more errors)
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 11.0.1
Node: 14.15.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 11.0.0
... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... localize, material, material-moment-adapter
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1100.1
@angular-devkit/build-angular   0.1100.1
@angular-devkit/core            11.0.1
@angular-devkit/schematics      11.0.1
@angular/cli                    11.0.1
@schematics/angular             11.0.1
@schematics/update              0.1100.1
rxjs                            6.6.3
typescript                      4.0.5

but as explained above this also happens on Angular 10

Issues.Title: Improve ng build --localize argument to accept locales instead of a boolean
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for `@angular/cli` and possibly `@angular/compiler-cli` `@angular/compiler` `@angular/localize`.


### Description
 The `--localize` argument for the `ng build` command currenty only accepts `true` or `false` which sets the locales from predefined configurations in the `angular.json` file.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Allow to set one or multiple locales through `ng build --localize=en` `ng build --localize=en,fr`. 


### Describe alternatives you've considered
The alternatives I found are;
- predefining each locale (and locale combination !) as a different configuration.
- building every locale

I believe both these alternatives do not fully benefit from the merits of the new faster way of making multiple localized builds.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Improve ng build --localize argument to accept locales instead of a boolean" (#19510)

Issues.Title: fix(@ngtools/webpack): remove use of Webpack compilation fileTimestamps property
Issues.Body: The `fileTimestamps` property on the Webpack compilation object no longer exists with Webpack 5.  This change uses the Webpack compiler's property of the same name instead.  The cache invalidation is also moved to a separate file and now calculates the changed file set as well.  This eliminates the second iteration of the file timestamps within the resource loader.

Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package core/cli The issue is caused by package @angular/.... ### Is this a regression? I think it is. Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description Hello, I just updated from 10 to 11. In my app I changed themes with lazy css replacement, like: ````json "styles": [ "apps/.../src/styles.scss", { "input": "apps/.../src/dark-styles.scss", "bundleName": "dark-styles", "inject": true, "lazy": true } ], ```` However, after migration `lazy` is no longer in the schema. Also, when I remove it themes do not work - ok, it generated `dark-styles` but with hashing. I've tried to add `outputHashing: false` to it, but also not present in the schema. What should I do? I cannot find any migration reference in this topic. Thanks. ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: Incorrect use of --directory param
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? No, this issue has been in the CLI for a long time ### Description When using the `--directory` param with the absolute path, the CLI does not respect the value and creates the directory path relative to the current directory instead. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Run the following command: ```shell ng new app1 --directory=/tmp/app1 --skip-install ``` Expected behaviour: The application is generated within `/tmp/app1` directory. Actual behaviour: The application is generated within current directory: `./tmp/app1` ## üåç Your Environment 


Angular CLI: 11.0.2
Node: 14.15.0
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 
...

@schematics/angular          11.0.2 (cli-only)

**Anything else relevant?** Using macOS

Issues.Title: Is extending of cdk-table recommended / supported?
Issues.Body:
Hi,

for one of the projects we need to use cdk tables with some of our logic on top.

While looking at mat-table, that extends cdk-table, we found out that the idea to extend the cdk-table might be not that bad.

However, the question is: is extension of cdk-table a valid approach?

It seems that there are some private injection tokens used https://github.com/angular/components/blob/4f776792d6a155b009ad410c63ded88a8a32af72/src/material/table/table.ts ; plus, generally the question of extending the classes that do not belong to you, might smell.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Is extending of cdk-table recommended / supported?" (#21174)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-datepicker): mat-datepicker is not displaying
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. add in a component a datepicker
```
          <mat-form-field appearance="fill">
            <mat-label>Choose a date</mat-label>
            <input matInput [matDatepicker]="picker">
            <mat-datepicker-toggle matSuffix [for]="picker"></mat-datepicker-toggle>
            <mat-datepicker #picker></mat-datepicker>
          </mat-form-field>
```
(code taken from [material angular doc / Basic datepicker](https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/overview))
2. refresh the page
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

It should display the datepicker inside the component

#### Actual Behavior

The whole component disappear from the page

#### Environment

- Angular CLI: 11.0.2
- @angular/material: 11.0.1
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): mac
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(mat-datepicker): mat-datepicker is not displaying" (#21164)

Issues.Title: bug(MatTooltip): A11y - Screen readers landmark issue with matTooltip
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
When using the `matTooltip` screen readers confused about the landmark and duplicate the announcement (e.g. main, list, group etc.).
This can make a lot of confusion for visually impaired users.
 
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-gizwqa?file=src%2Fapp%2Ftooltip-overview-example.html

Steps to reproduce (in the example above):
1. Navigate to the first button with keyboard (using <kbd>Tab</kbd> key).
2. Screen reader will announce the new landmark, the button and the tooltip: _My buttons grouping Button1 button  Info about the action_
3. Navigate to second and last buttons, in the last button the landmark will be announced again.
4. Navigate only throw 2 last buttons - the screen reader will announce only the button as expected.
5. Navigate to the first button - the landmark will be announced again (and so on the last 3 button).
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Screen readers will announce the landmark only once (when entering to the landmark)
In the example:
- My buttons grouping Button1 button  Info about the action
- Button2 button
- Button3 button


#### Actual Behavior

Screen readers duplicated the announcement.
In the example:
- My buttons grouping Button1 button  Info about the action
- Button2 button
- My buttons grouping Button3 button

#### Environment

- Angular: 11.0.2 (also in V10)
- CDK/Material: 11.0.1
- Browser(s): Chrome V87
(tested with NVDA in Firefox and worked as expected).
- Screen readers: NVDA V2020.2, JAWS 2020
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatTooltip): A11y - Screen readers landmark issue with matTooltip" (#21173)

Issues.Title: Angular Material Charts
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

I would like to propose Angular Material Charts, an integrated charting library built in Angular, ready to go!

As we all know, having the angular team providing components has a number of benefits, like compatibility, same day release, etc. Having to use another library for such an essential feature is a bit of a turn down.

#### Use Case

There is a growing need to display Analytic data, the potential use cases are infinite. 
I think the simpler apps could benefit from it specially.

I found a couple of issues regarding this topic #12867 #13940 . It's been 2 years now.


Any thoughts?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular Material Charts" (#21172)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-expansion-panel): header position is incorrect when call elementInsideMatExpansionPanel.scrollIntoView(true)
Issues.Body: #### Reproduction - Components: https://angular-mat-expansion-panel-header-gone-after-scrollintoview.stackblitz.io Steps to reproduce: 1. open [StackBlitz reproduce example](https://angular-mat-expansion-panel-header-gone-after-scrollintoview.stackblitz.io) 2. scroll to bottom 3. click `Test ScrollIntoView` button. or. 1. Add `test` inside `mat-expansion-panel` tag. 2. Set `mat-expansion-panel` `expanded="false"`. 3. Call `elementInsideMatExpansionPanel.scrollIntoView(true)`, e.g. `document.querySelector('.bug-target').scrollIntoView(true)`. #### Expected Behavior Viewport scrolls to `mat-expansion-panel` with `mat-expansion-panel-header` display, and element inside `mat-expansion-panel` remains hidden. #### Actual Behavior Viewport scrolls to `mat-expansion-panel` and causes `mat-expansion-panel-header` x-position changed and `mat-expansion-panel-header` is not display. #### Environment - Angular: 11.0.1 - CDK/Material: 11.0.1 - Browser(s): Chrome Version 87.0.4280.66 (Official Build) (64-bit) - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows, Ubutntu #### Workaround Call `window.scroll` or `scrollTo` function, see [StackBlitz reproduce example](https://angular-mat-expansion-panel-header-gone-after-scrollintoview.stackblitz.io)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-expansion-panel): header position is incorrect when call elementInsideMatExpansionPanel.scrollIntoView(true)" (#21159)

Issues.Title: feat(table): MatCellHarness should extend ContentContainerComponentHarness
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

`MatCellHarness` should extend from `ContentContainerComponentHarness` instead of `ComponentHarness` so it exposes (at least) the `getHarness` and `getAllHarnesses` methods to scope the loading of harnesses.

#### Use Case

Quite often it is the case that a table cell has more than just text content (like a custom icon component). It would be nice if the `MatCellHarness` would expose the methods of `ContentContainerComponentHarness` to load harnesses within the table cell. From the docs I can see that `ContentContainerComponentHarness` is meant for components that have a `ng-content` slot, and in a way a table cell is exactly that.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(table): MatCellHarness should extend ContentContainerComponentHarness" (#21157)

Issues.Title: fix(material/slider): unable to assign min/max values if they are more precise than then step
Issues.Body:
We have some logic that trims the value to the same number of decimals as the `step`, in order to avoid assigning long decimal values. The problem is that if the `min` or `max` are more precise than the `step`, we round up just above the `min` or below the `max`, preventing the user from reaching the end values.

These changes add an exception to the rounding for the `min` and `max` values.

Fixes #21147.

Issues.Title: MatMenu aria-label is not cleared from dummy element
Issues.Body:
`<mat-menu>` is a dummy element whose content is extracted and rendered into an overlay. We forward `aria-label` to the real menu, but we currently don't clear this label from the dummy element, leading to it being ready by screen-readers. We should do one of:
* Clear the forwarded attributes
* Add `aria-hidden`
* Just completely remove the dummy element from the DOM

Until this is fixed, people can work around the issue by using a binding, e.g. `[aria-label]="'Settings menu'"`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatMenu aria-label is not cleared from dummy element" (#21152)
